originalTitle: Catch of the day: Pictures from spectacular Nigerian fishing festival
title: Big Fish, Big Smiles: A Festival for Friends in Nigeria!
content:
Hello from Africa!

Welcome, my little friends, to another exciting story from wonderful Africa! I'm your friendly news reporter, here to tell you about something super special. Today, we're going on an adventure to a country called Nigeria. Get ready to hear about a big party that helps everyone be friends and catch lots of fish! Did you know? Africa is a huge continent with many different countries and amazing animals!

What is a Fishing Festival?

Imagine a big, happy party. But this party is all about fish! It's called a fishing festival. People come from many different villages and towns. They all come together for a few days to celebrate and have fun. The most exciting part is the big fishing contest! It's like a big family gathering, but with thousands of people! Everyone is excited to see who can catch the biggest fish.

Where is This Happening?

This special festival happens in Nigeria. Nigeria is a very big country in West Africa. It has long rivers and beautiful lakes. The festival takes place right by one of these big rivers, where lots of fish swim. The water sparkles under the sun, waiting for the big competition. Did you know? Nigeria has many different languages, but English is also spoken there, just like in your classroom!

How Do They Fish?

This isn't like fishing with a tiny pole and a worm! Oh no, this is much bigger! Many men jump into the water at the same time. They hold large, special fishing nets. These nets are very wide, almost like big blankets. When the signal is given, they throw their nets into the water very, very fast! They try to scoop up as many fish as they can. It's a fantastic sight to see all the nets flying through the air! It takes a lot of skill and strength to throw these big nets. The fishermen practice all year for this special day.

Finding the Biggest Fish!

This is the part everyone waits for! After a lot of splashing and cheering, the fishermen come out of the water with their catches. They bring their fish to special judges. The judges carefully look at each fish. They want to find the biggest, heaviest fish of all! Imagine seeing a fish as long as your whole arm, or even bigger! People gather around, excited to see who will win. The person who catches the champion fish gets a very special prize. It's a big honour! Did you know? Some fish can live for many, many years, even longer than your grandparents!

Why is This Festival Special?

Now, here's the most important part of our story. This festival is not just about catching fish. It's about something much, much bigger. It's about helping people in the community be friends. Sometimes, people in different villages might have arguments. But this festival helps them remember that they are all part of one big family. It helps them put their differences aside and smile together. It's a way to make sure everyone lives in peace. Peace means being kind to each other. It means talking instead of shouting. It means sharing toys and helping friends. When everyone lives in peace, everyone is happy and safe. This festival helps make that happen.

More Than Just Fishing!

The festival is packed with other exciting things to do! While some people are fishing, others are singing and dancing. Traditional music plays loudly, and people move their feet to the happy beat. Children laugh and play games. There is also lots of yummy food to eat! People share meals and tell stories. It's a wonderful time for families to spend together and for friends to make new memories. The air is full of joy and the smell of delicious food. Did you know? Festivals like this are a very important part of culture. They help people remember their history and traditions.

Everyone is a Winner!

Even if someone doesn't catch the biggest fish, everyone feels like a winner at this festival. Why? Because they win something even better than a prize – they win friendship and happiness! They get to spend time with their neighbours and friends. It's about having fun together, sharing smiles, and being part of a big, loving community. When people come together like this, their towns become stronger and happier.

Let's Be Friends!

The Nigerian fishing festival teaches us all a very big and important lesson. It teaches us to be kind to each other. It teaches us to share. And most importantly, it teaches us that living in peace is the best way to be happy. This is good for every single person and every single family. So, next time you see someone new, remember the big fishing festival in Nigeria. Remember to smile, be kind, and try to make new friends. Because when we are all friends, the world is a much brighter and happier place! What a wonderful lesson from Africa!
summary: Children, hear about a special fishing festival in Nigeria where people catch big fish, dance, eat yummy food, and most importantly, remember to be friends and live in peace.
whyMatters: This festival is super important because it helps people from different places come together, solve their problems, and remember to be kind and friendly, making their whole community happy and safe.

originalTitle: Rare prison sentences handed to Cameroon soldiers after killing of 21 civilians
title: Rare prison sentences handed to Cameroon soldiers after killing of 21 civilians
content: In a rare occurence, three soldiers were handed jail terms for killings in the troubled Anglophone region.

title: South African farmers fear devastation as foot-and-mouth takes hold
content: The government has begun a vaccination programme but officials have been blamed for a slow response.

title: Iran’s president says his country will not bow to US pressure
content: Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian says Tehran will not bow to US pressure over nuclear talks.

originalTitle: Attacked in India, Kashmiri shawl sellers choose between safety, livelihood
title: Attacked in India, Kashmiri shawl sellers choose between safety, livelihood
content: A surge in attacks has forced many Kashmiris to return home. Others are devising survival strategies.

originalTitle: How Russia has weaponised winter against people in Ukraine
title: How Russia has weaponised winter against people in Ukraine
content: Russia has struck Ukraine's energy grid 2,500 times in four years, leaving millions without heat in freezing weather.

originalTitle: Iran students stage first large anti-government protests since deadly crackdown
title: Iran students stage first large anti-government protests since deadly crackdown
content: The student protesters honoured thousands of those killed when nationwide mass protests were put down last month.

originalTitle: More than 1,500 Venezuelan political prisoners apply for amnesty
title: More than 1,500 Venezuelan political prisoners apply for amnesty
content: The announcement by the head of Venezuela's National Assembly comes amid US pressure following the capture of ex-President Nicolás Maduro.

originalTitle: Final missing Lake Tahoe skier found dead 5 days after avalanche
title: Final missing Lake Tahoe skier found dead 5 days after avalanche
content: Authorities released the names of the six women and three guides who died in the worst avalanche in state history.

originalTitle: O'Reilly scores twice as Man City beat Newcastle
title: O'Reilly scores twice as Man City beat Newcastle
content: Manchester City move to within two points of Premier League leaders Arsenal with a tense victory against Newcastle United at Etihad Stadium.

originalTitle: Ten-man Chelsea drop points again as Burnley score stoppage-time equaliser
title: Ten-man Chelsea drop points again as Burnley score stoppage-time equaliser
content: Chelsea make it 17 points dropped from winning positions in the Premier League this season as Zian Flemming's 93rd-minute header gives Burnley a 1-1 draw, after Wesley Fofana is sent off at Stamford Bridge.

originalTitle: Late Abraham goal rescues point for Villa against Leeds
title: Late Abraham goal rescues point for Villa against Leeds
content: Tammy Abraham comes off the bench to score an 88th minute equaliser to cancel out Anton Stach's spectacular freekick, as Aston Villa rescue a 1-1 draw against Leeds United at Villa Park in the Premier League.
